result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Jury selection scheduled for May 15, 2023 at 08:00 am.
Jury trial scheduled for May 15, 2023 at 08:00 am.
Calendar call on August 22, 2022 at 09:30 am.

Activity: Preliminary hearing and Arraignment
Appearances by video/zoom: Court Official, Court Reporter, Court Clerk, and all Parties referenced in hearing minutes as in court.

9:02 AM Defendant Shanice Reena Foreman in court by video with attorney Walter H Isaacson by video. Mason C Braunschweig appeared by video for the State of Wisconsin. Officer Kailey Kinsella of Janesville Police Department sworn testimony taken by video; Witness identified the defendant. State moves for bind over, defense objects. Court finds probable cause and binds Defendant over for filing of an Information. Information filed, copy to Defendant's attorney, reading waived. Defendant's attorney pleads not guilty and jury trial to be set, bond to continue.
Preliminary hearing on May 10, 2022 at 09:00 am.
